wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total reserves minus gold (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total reserves minus gold comprise special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. Gold holdings are excluded. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of SMEs who have a female senior manager with an outstanding loan or line of credit (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises, having a female senior manager, with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of female-owned SMEs with an outstanding loan or line of credit (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of female-owned, small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of large enterprises with an outstanding loan or line of credit (100+ employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of medium enterprises with an outstanding loan or line of credit (20-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of SMEs who have a male senior manager with an outstanding loan or line of credit (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises, having a male senior manager, with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of male-owned SMEs with an outstanding loan or line of credit (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of male-owned, small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of small enterprises with an outstanding loan or line of credit (5-19 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) enterprises with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of SMEs with an outstanding loan or line of credit (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a loan or line of credit from a regulated financial institution at the time of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of SMEs who have a female senior manager with an account at a formal financial institution (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises, having a female senior manager, with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of female-owned SMEs with an account at a formal financial institution (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of female-owned, small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of large enterprises with an account at a formal financial institution (100+ employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of large (100+ employees) enterprises with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of medium enterprises with an account at a formal financial institution (20-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of SMEs who have a male senior manager with an account at a formal financial institution (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises, having a male senior manager, with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of male-owned SMEs with an account at a formal financial institution (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of male-owned small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of small enterprises with an account at a formal financial institution (5-19 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) enterprises with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percent of SMEs with an account at a formal financial institution (5-99 employees)
wb:indicator.wb:source: G20 Basic Set of Financial Inclusion Indicators
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Denotes the percentage of small (5-19 employees) or medium (20-99 employees) enterprises with a checking or savings account.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Enterprise Surveys

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fishmeal, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fishmeal (any origin), 64-65%, c&f Bremen, estimates based on wholesale price, beginning 2004; previously c&f Hamburg
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ISTA Mielke GmbH, Oil World; US Department of Agriculture; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Change in domestic credit to the private sector covers changes in claims on private non-financial corporations, households, and non-profit institutions. Data; Annual flow, local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit is the sum of net credit to the non financial public sector, credit to the private sector, and other accounts. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to government, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Change in domestic credit to government includes changes in net claims on central government, and changes in claims on state and local government as well as on non-financial public corporations. Data; Annual flow, local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on central government, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to government budget. Data are in current local currencies. AF stands for annual flow.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total assets, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Change in liabilities consists of changes in money, quasi-money and other liabilities, net. Data; Annual flow, local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net foreign assets, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net foreign assets are the sum of foreign assets held by monetary authorities and deposit money banks, less their foreign liabilities. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on other official entities, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to other official entities of government. Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on nonmonetary financial institutions, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to other financial institutions (non-governmental). Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector and other financial institutions, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to Rest of the economy (excludes government). Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on central government (annual growth as % of broad money)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on central government (IFS line 32AN..ZK) include loans to central government institutions net of deposits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to private sector, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 32S..ZK) include gross credit from the financial system to households, nonprofit institutions serving households, nonfinancial corporations, state and local governments, and social security funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (annual growth as % of broad money)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 32S..ZK) include gross credit from the financial system to households, nonprofit institutions serving households, nonfinancial corporations, state and local governments, and social security funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit is the sum of net claims on the central government and claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 32). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on governments and other public entities (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises, advances against future credit authorizations, and purchases of treasury bills and bonds, net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on governments and other public entities (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises, advances against future credit authorizations, and purchases of treasury bills and bonds, net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "International Monetary Fund. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on governments, etc. (annual growth as % of M2)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on governments and other public entities (IFS line 32an + 32b + 32bx + 32c) usually comprise direct credit for specific purposes such as financing of the government budget deficit or loans to state enterprises, advances against future credit authorizations, and purchases of treasury bills and bonds, net of deposits by the public sector. Public sector deposits with the banking system also include sinking funds for the service of debt and temporary deposits of government revenues. Money and quasi money (M2) comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on central government (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on the central government, net is defined as the central governments direct financial obligations to the country’s financial institutions less any claims the central government has on those institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total assets (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Liabilities consists of money, quasi-money and other liabilities, net, end of year stocks.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net foreign assets (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net foreign assets are the sum of foreign assets held by monetary authorities and deposit money banks, less their foreign liabilities. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net foreign assets (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net foreign assets are the sum of foreign assets held by monetary authorities and deposit money banks, less their foreign liabilities. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to other official entities, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to other official entities of government. Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to other private financial institutions, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to other financial institutions of the Rest of the economy (excludes government). Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector (annual growth as % of M2)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on private sector (IFS line 32d) include gross credit from the financial system to individuals, enterprises, nonfinancial public entities not included under net domestic credit, and financial institutions not included elsewhere. Money and quasi money (M2) comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on private sector (annual growth as % of broad money)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on private sector (IFS line 32D..ZK or 32D..ZF) include gross credit from the financial system to individuals, enterprises, nonfinancial public entities not included under net domestic credit, and financial institutions not included elsewhere.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net domestic credit to rest of economy, stock (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net domestic credit to Rest of the economy (excludes government). Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2), flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money (M2), flow (current LCU) is the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other liabilities excluding M2, flow (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other liabilities excluding M2 (current LCU).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Broad money (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Broad money (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Broad money to total reserves ratio
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Broad money growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Broad money (IFS line 35L..ZK) is the sum of currency outside banks; demand deposits other than those of the central government; the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government; bank and traveler’s checks; and other securities such as certificates of deposit and commercial paper.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money is the sum of currency outside banks and demand deposits other than those of central government. This series, frequently referred to as M1 is a narrower definition of money than M2. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2) (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition of money supply is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2) as % of GDP
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition of money supply is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money (M2) to total reserves ratio
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities. The gold component of these reserves is valued at year-end (December 31) London prices.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money and quasi money growth (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Average annual growth rate in money and quasi money. Money and quasi money comprise the sum of currency outside banks, demand deposits other than those of the central government, and the time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government. This definition is frequently called M2; it corresponds to lines 34 and 35 in the International Monetary Fund's (IMF) International Financial Statistics (IFS). The change in the money supply is measured as the difference in end-of-year totals relative to the level of M2 in the preceding year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Quasi money (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Quasi money refers to time, savings, and foreign currency deposits of resident sectors other than the central government.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other liabilities excluding M2 (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other liabilities excluding M2, flow (current LCU).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central bank intervention rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Central bank intervention rate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Consumer price index (2010 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumer price index reflects changes in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Inflation, consumer prices (annual %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Inflation as measured by the consumer price index reflects the annual percentage change in the cost to the average consumer of acquiring a basket of goods and services that may be fixed or changed at specified intervals, such as yearly. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wholesale price index (2010 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wholesale price index refers to a mix of agricultural and industrial goods at various stages of production and distribution, including import duties. The Laspeyres formula is generally used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Deposit interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Deposit interest rate is the rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand, time, or savings deposits. The terms and conditions attached to these rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real deposit interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Real interest rate is the lending interest rate adjusted for inflation as measured by the GDP deflator.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files using World Bank data on the GDP deflator.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Bond interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Bond interest rate (%).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: International interest rate, implicit (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: International interest rate (implicit, %).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lending interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Lending rate is the bank rate that usually meets the short- and medium-term financing needs of the private sector. This rate is normally differentiated according to creditworthiness of borrowers and objectives of financing. The terms and conditions attached to these rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest rate spread (lending rate minus deposit rate, %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest rate spread is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to private sector customers minus the interest rate paid by commercial or similar banks for demand, time, or savings deposits. The terms and conditions attached to these rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Money market rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Money market interest rate, IFS line 60b (%).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Real interest rate is the lending interest rate adjusted for inflation as measured by the GDP deflator.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files using World Bank data on the GDP deflator.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Risk premium on lending (lending rate minus treasury bill rate, %)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Risk premium on lending is the interest rate charged by banks on loans to private sector customers minus the "risk free" treasury bill interest rate at which short-term government securities are issued or traded in the market. In some countries this spread may be negative, indicating that the market considers its best corporate clients to be lower risk than the government. The terms and conditions attached to lending rates differ by country, however, limiting their comparability.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time deposits interest rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest, deposit rate, shows the average rate offered by banks to resident customers for demand, time, and savings deposits. This item is equal to line 60l..zf in the IMFs International Financial Statistics publication.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real interest on time deposit (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: IFS, line 60 lc deflated by CPI.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on central government, etc. (% GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on central government (IFS line 52AN or 32AN) include loans to central government institutions net of deposits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Claims on other sectors of the domestic economy (IFS line 52S or 32S) include gross credit from the financial system to households, nonprofit institutions serving households, nonfinancial corporations, state and local governments, and social security funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Domestic credit provided by financial sector (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic credit provided by the financial sector includes all credit to various sectors on a gross basis, with the exception of credit to the central government, which is net. The financial sector includes monetary authorities and deposit money banks, as well as other financial corporations where data are available (including corporations that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other financial corporations are finance and leasing companies, money lenders, insurance corporations, pension funds, and foreign exchange companies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Banking survey: claims on private sector (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector, such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Domestic credit to private sector (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic credit to private sector refers to financial resources provided to the private sector by financial corporations, such as through loans, purchases of nonequity securities, and trade credits and other accounts receivable, that establish a claim for repayment. For some countries these claims include credit to public enterprises. The financial corporations include monetary authorities and deposit money banks, as well as other financial corporations where data are available (including corporations that do not accept transferable deposits but do incur such liabilities as time and savings deposits). Examples of other financial corporations are finance and leasing companies, money lenders, insurance corporations, pension funds, and foreign exchange companies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Liquid liabilities (M3) as % of GDP
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Liquid liabilities are also known as M3. They are the sum of currency and deposits in the central bank (M0), plus transferable deposits and electronic currency (M1), plus time and savings deposits, foreign currency transferable deposits, certificates of deposit, and securities repurchase agreements (M2), plus travelers checks, foreign currency time deposits, commercial paper, and shares of mutual funds or market funds held by residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Quasi-liquid liabilities (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Quasi-liquid liabilities are the sum of currency and deposits in the central bank (M0), plus time and savings deposits, foreign currency transferable deposits, certificates of deposit, and securities repurchase agreements, plus travelers checks, foreign currency time deposits, commercial paper, and shares of mutual funds or market funds held by residents. They equal the M3 money supply less transferable deposits and electronic currency (M1).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Demand deposits (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Demand deposits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time deposits (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time deposits.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjustments to foreign scheduled principal repayments (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid in currency, goods, or services in the year specified.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists

wb:indicator.wb:name: Current budget balance, including grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The excess of current revenue over current expenditure. data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Overall budget balance, including grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Overall budget deficit is current and capital revenue and official grants received, less total expenditure and lending minus repayments. Data are shown for central government only, and are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Overall surplus/deficit, excluding current grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Overall budget surplus/deficit (excluding current grants) is current and capital revenue excluding current grants, less total expenditure and lending minus repayments. Data are shown for central government only, and are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Overall surplus/deficit, excluding all grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Overall budget deficit is current and capital revenue excluding current grants less total expenditure and lending minus repayments. Values are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary balance, excluding interest (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary deficit, excluding interest (current LCU).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt, monetary system credit (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic debt consists of the outstanding stock or recognized, direct liabilities to the monetary system. Data are in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt, other domestic (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic debt to other in current local currencies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank and Global Development Finance.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External debt, end year (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Foreign debt consists of the outstanding stock or recognized, direct liabilities of the government to the rest of the world, generated in the past and scheduled to be extinguished by government operations in the future or to continue as perpetual debt. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External debt, end year (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Foreign debt consists of the outstanding stock or recognized, direct liabilities of the government to the rest of the world, generated in the past and scheduled to be extinguished by government operations in the future or to continue as perpetual debt. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total government debt (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government arrears on domestic debt (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Central government arrears on domestic debt. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government arrears on external debt (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Central government arrears on external debt. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External borrowing, net (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Financing from abroad (obtained from nonresidents) refer to the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. It includes all government liabilities--other. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Domestic financing, monetary system credit (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic financing, monetary system credit. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other domestic borrowing (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Domestic financing (obtained from residents) refer to the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. It includes all government liabilities--other than those for currency issues or demand, time, or savings deposits with government--or claims on others held by government and changes in government holdings of cash and deposits. Government guarantees of the debt of others are excluded. Data are shown for central government only, and are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Financing, including external capital grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Financing, including external capital grants. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total current grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Grants include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: External capital grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Grants are unrequited, nonrepayable, noncompulsory receipts of government from other governments or international institutions. In determination of the deficit/surplus, grants are grouped with revenue and expenditure rather than with financing. Values are
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nontax receipts (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Receipts from sources other than the tax system like property income, fees, fines, and contributions to government employee pension funds within government. Data ate in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total revenue including current grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total revenue and grants equals the sum of government revenue and grants. Revenue includes all nonrepayable and nonrepaying government receipts other than grants. Grants are defined as unrequited, nonrepayable, noncompulsory receipts. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government revenue excluding all grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Central government revenue excluding all grants. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government revenues, excluding all grants (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Central government revenues, excluding all grants.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total currrent revenues including current grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current revenue (including grants) includes all revenue from taxes and current nontax revenues such as fines, fees, recoveries, and income from property or sales, and grants. Data are shown for central government only, and are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Current revenue, excluding grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists

wb:indicator.wb:name: Capital revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Capital revenue comprises proceeds from the sale of nonfinancial capital assets, including land, intangible assets, stocks, and fixed capital assets of buildings, construction and equipment of more than a minimum value and usable for more than one year in the process of production, and receipts of unrequited transfers for capital purposes from nongovernmental sources. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Highest marginal tax rate, corporate rate (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Highest marginal tax rate (corporate rate) is the highest rate shown on the schedule of tax rates applied to the taxable income of corporations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: KPMG's Corporate and Indirect Tax Rate Survey 2009 (www.kpmg.com), and PricewaterhouseCoopers's Worldwide Tax Summaries Online (www.pwc.com).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Direct taxes (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Direct taxes on goods and services include all taxes and duties levied on production, extraction, sale, transfer, leasing, or delivery of goods and rendering of services, or in respect of the use of goods, or permission to use goods or to perform activities, are covered. Examples include all general sales taxes, value added taxes and excises. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services, GB (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include all taxes and duties levied by central governments on the production, extraction, sale, transfer, leasing, or delivery of goods and rendering of services, or on the use of goods or permission to use goods or perform activities. These include general sales taxes, turnover or value added taxes, excise taxes, and motor vehicle taxes. Data are shown for central government only and are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Indirect taxes less subsidies (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Indirect taxes are the sum of indirect taxes less subsidies. Indirect taxes are those taxes payable by producers that relate to the production, sale, purchase or use of the goods and services. Subsidies are grants on the current account made by general government to private enterprises and unincorporated public enterprises. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on international trade, GB (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes. Current revenue includes all revenue from taxes and nonrepayable receipts (other than grants) from the sale of land, intangible assets, government stocks, or fixed capital assets, or from capital transfers from nongovernmental sources. It also includes fines, fees, recoveries, inheritance taxes, and nonrecurrent levies on capital. Data are shown for central government only. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjustments to foreign scheduled debt service (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date such as money deposits, securities, shares and loans. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt service, external (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date such as money deposits, securities, shares and loans. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government consumption (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current expenditure on goods and services comprises payments of wages and salaries in cash to employees (including the armed forces) before deduction of withholding taxes and employees' contributions to social security and pension funds, as well as employers' contributions to superannuation schemes outside government, and other purchases of goods and services (wages and salaries in kind, office supplies and maintenance charges etc.). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest on domestic debt (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest on domestic debt. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest on external debt (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest on external debt (current LCU). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies (GFS, current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies are current unrequited payments that government units make to enterprises, resident producers and importers. Subsidies may be designed to influence enterprises level or type of production, or the prices at which the products are sold. (Capital grants are in the national accounts classified as capital transfers.) Subsidies consists of ‘subsidies on products’, subsidies payable per unit of a good or a service, and ‘other subsidies on production’, which cover all other subsidies enterprises receives as a consequence of engaging in production. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Current expenditure, total (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total current expenditure includes requited payments other than for capital assets or for goods or services to be used in the production of capital assets, and unrequited payments for purposes other than permitting the recipients to acquire capital assets, compensating the recipients for damage or destruction of capital assets, or increasing the financial capital of the recipients. Data are shown for central government only. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other current transfers (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other current transfers include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wages and salaries (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wages and salaries consist of all payments in cash, but not in kind, to employees in return for services rendered, before deduction of withholding taxes and employees contributions to social security and pension funds. Data are shown for central government only. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Defense expenditure (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Defense expenditures for NATO countries are based on the NATO definition, which covers military-related expenditures of the defense ministry (including recruiting, training, construction, and the purchase of military supplies and equipment) and other ministries. Civilian-type expenditures of the defense ministry are excluded. Military assistance is included in the expenditures of the donor country, and purchases of military equipment on credit are included at the time the debt is incurred, not at the time of payment. Data for other countries generally cover expenditures of the ministry of defense (excluded are expenditures on public order and safety, which are classified separately). Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total expenditure and net lending (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total expenditure and net lending includes both current and capital (development) expenditures and includes lending minus repayments. Data are shown for central government only. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Research and development expenditure (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expenditures for research and development are current and capital expenditures (both public and private) on creative work undertaken systematically to increase knowledge, including knowledge of humanity, culture, and society, and the use of knowledge for new applications. R&D covers basic research, applied research, and experimental development.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total capital expenditure and net lending (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expenditure for acquisition of land, intangible assets, government stocks, and nonmilitary and nonfinancial assets; also for capital grants and lending minus repayments. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Budgetary investment (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Budgetary investment. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists

wb:indicator.wb:name: Capital transfers (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Capital transfers. Data are in current local currency.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fiscal balance, cash surplus/deficit (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cash surplus or deficit is revenue (including grants) minus expense, minus net acquisition of nonfinancial assets. In the 1986 GFS manual nonfinancial assets were included under revenue and expenditure in gross terms. This cash surplus or deficit is closest to the earlier overall budget balance (still missing is lending minus repayments, which are now a financing item under net acquisition of financial assets).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cash surplus/deficit (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cash surplus or deficit is revenue (including grants) minus expense, minus net acquisition of nonfinancial assets. In the 1986 GFS manual nonfinancial assets were included under revenue and expenditure in gross terms. This cash surplus or deficit is closest to the earlier overall budget balance (still missing is lending minus repayments, which are now a financing item under net acquisition of financial assets).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cash surplus/deficit (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cash surplus or deficit is revenue (including grants) minus expense, minus net acquisition of nonfinancial assets. In the 1986 GFS manual nonfinancial assets were included under revenue and expenditure in gross terms. This cash surplus or deficit is closest to the earlier overall budget balance (still missing is lending minus repayments, which are now a financing item under net acquisition of financial assets).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt, total (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Central government debt, total (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Debt is the entire stock of direct government fixed-term contractual obligations to others outstanding on a particular date. It includes domestic and foreign liabilities such as currency and money deposits, securities other than shares, and loans. It is the gross amount of government liabilities reduced by the amount of equity and financial derivatives held by the government. Because debt is a stock rather than a flow, it is measured as of a given date, usually the last day of the fiscal year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, domestic (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, domestic (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, foreign (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net incurrence of liabilities, foreign (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net incurrence of government liabilities includes foreign financing (obtained from nonresidents) and domestic financing (obtained from residents), or the means by which a government provides financial resources to cover a budget deficit or allocates financial resources arising from a budget surplus. The net incurrence of liabilities should be offset by the net acquisition of financial assets (a third financing item). The difference between the cash surplus or deficit and the three financing items is the net change in the stock of cash.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Grants and other revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Grants and other revenue include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; interest; dividends; rent; requited, nonrepayable receipts for public purposes (such as fines, administrative fees, and entrepreneurial income from government owner­ship of property); and voluntary, unrequited, nonrepayable receipts other than grants.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Grants and other revenue (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Grants and other revenue include grants from other foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; interest; dividends; rent; requited, nonrepayable receipts for public purposes (such as fines, administrative fees, and entrepreneurial income from government owner­ship of property); and voluntary, unrequited, nonrepayable receipts other than grants.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Social contributions (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Social contributions include social security contributions by employees, employers, and self-employed individuals, and other contributions whose source cannot be determined. They also include actual or imputed contributions to social insurance schemes operated by governments.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Social contributions (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Social contributions include social security contributions by employees, employers, and self-employed individuals, and other contributions whose source cannot be determined. They also include actual or imputed contributions to social insurance schemes operated by governments.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total revenue (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Current revenue includes all revenue from taxes and nonrepayable receipts (other than grants) from the sale of land, intangible assets, government stocks or fixed capital assets, or from capital transfers from nongovernmental sources. It also includes inheritance taxes and nonrecurrent levies on capital. Data are in current US dollar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue, excluding grants (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here. Data are in current US dollar.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue, excluding grants (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Revenue, excluding grants (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Revenue is cash receipts from taxes, social contributions, and other revenues such as fines, fees, rent, and income from property or sales. Grants are also considered as revenue but are excluded here.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on exports (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on exports are all levies on goods being transported out of the country or services being delivered to nonresidents by residents. Rebates on exported goods that are repayments of previously paid general consumption taxes, excise taxes, or import duties are deducted from the gross amounts receivable from these taxes, not from amounts receivable from export taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on exports (% of tax revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on exports are all levies on goods being transported out of the country or services being delivered to nonresidents by residents. Rebates on exported goods that are repayments of previously paid general consumption taxes, excise taxes, or import duties are deducted from the gross amounts receivable from these taxes, not from amounts receivable from export taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on goods and services (% value added of industry and services)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on goods and services include general sales and turnover or value added taxes, selective excises on goods, selective taxes on services, taxes on the use of goods or property, taxes on extraction and production of minerals, and profits of fiscal monopolies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD value added estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Customs and other import duties (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Customs and other import duties are all levies collected on goods that are entering the country or services delivered by nonresidents to residents. They include levies imposed for revenue or protection purposes and determined on a specific or ad valorem basis as long as they are restricted to imported goods or services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Customs and other import duties (% of tax revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Customs and other import duties are all levies collected on goods that are entering the country or services delivered by nonresidents to residents. They include levies imposed for revenue or protection purposes and determined on a specific or ad valorem basis as long as they are restricted to imported goods or services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on international trade (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on international trade (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on international trade include import duties, export duties, profits of export or import monopolies, exchange profits, and exchange taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other taxes (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other taxes include employer payroll or labor taxes, taxes on property, and taxes not allocable to other categories, such as penalties for late payment or nonpayment of taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other taxes (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other taxes include employer payroll or labor taxes, taxes on property, and taxes not allocable to other categories, such as penalties for late payment or nonpayment of taxes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tax revenue (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tax revenue refers to compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Certain compulsory transfers such as fines, penalties, and most social security contributions are excluded. Refunds and corrections of erroneously collected tax revenue are treated as negative revenue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tax revenue (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tax revenue refers to compulsory transfers to the central government for public purposes. Certain compulsory transfers such as fines, penalties, and most social security contributions are excluded. Refunds and corrections of erroneously collected tax revenue are treated as negative revenue.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on income, profits and capital gains (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on income, profits and capital gains (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Taxes on income, profits and capital gains (% of total taxes)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Taxes on income, profits, and capital gains are levied on the actual or presumptive net income of individuals, on the profits of corporations and enterprises, and on capital gains, whether realized or not, on land, securities, and other assets. Intragovernmental payments are eliminated in consolidation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Compensation of employees (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compensation of employees consists of all payments in cash, as well as in kind (such as food and housing), to employees in return for services rendered, and government contributions to social insurance schemes such as social security and pensions that provide benefits to employees.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Compensation of employees (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Compensation of employees consists of all payments in cash, as well as in kind (such as food and housing), to employees in return for services rendered, and government contributions to social insurance schemes such as social security and pensions that provide benefits to employees.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Goods and services expense (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Goods and services include all government payments in exchange for goods and services used for the production of market and nonmarket goods and services. Own-account capital formation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Goods and services expense (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Goods and services include all government payments in exchange for goods and services used for the production of market and nonmarket goods and services. Own-account capital formation is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest payments (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest payments (% of revenue)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Interest payments (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Interest payments include interest payments on government debt--including long-term bonds, long-term loans, and other debt instruments--to domestic and foreign residents.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other expense (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other expense is spending on dividends, rent, and other miscellaneous expenses, including provision for consumption of fixed capital.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other expense (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Other expense is spending on dividends, rent, and other miscellaneous expenses, including provision for consumption of fixed capital.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expense (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expense (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expense (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expense is cash payments for operating activities of the government in providing goods and services. It includes compensation of employees (such as wages and salaries), interest and subsidies, grants, social benefits, and other expenses such as rent and dividends.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies and other transfers (current LCU)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies, grants, and other social benefits include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises; grants to foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; and social security, social assistance benefits, and employer social benefits in cash and in kind.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Subsidies and other transfers (% of expense)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Subsidies, grants, and other social benefits include all unrequited, nonrepayable transfers on current account to private and public enterprises; grants to foreign governments, international organizations, and other government units; and social security, social assistance benefits, and employer social benefits in cash and in kind.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Government Finance Statistics Yearbook and data files.
